meanings.def: not able to see
examples: Doctors think he will go blind.
She went blind at the age of ten.
blind and partially sighted people
One of her parents is blind.
She has been legally blind since birth.
The accident left her blind in one eye.

meanings.def: people who are blind
examples: recorded books for the blind
guide dogs for the blind

meanings.def: not noticing or realizing something
examples: She is blind to her husband's faults.
I must have been blind not to realize the danger we were in.
They seem to be totally blind to reality.
The government is not blind to the fact that the national debt is increasing.
His own problems have made him completely blind to the sufferings of others.
Is the public wilfully blind to what is going on?

meanings.def: seeming to be unreasonable, and accepted without question; seeming to be out of control
examples: blind faith/obedience
It was a moment of blind panic.

meanings.def: that cannot be controlled by reason
examples: blind chance
the blind force of nature

meanings.def: that a driver in a car cannot see, or cannot see around
examples: a blind driveway
a blind bend/corner

meanings.def: that does not make a difference between people on the basis of the quality mentioned, or favour one group over another
examples: In a piece of gender-blind casting, Hamlet is played by British actress Maxine Peake.
We are looking to create a more equitable and race-blind society.

meanings.def: not able to see well
examples: She’s as blind as a bat without her glasses.

meanings.def: a situation in which people with almost no experience or knowledge give advice to others who also have no experience or knowledge
when you love somebody, you cannot see their faults
not any
examples: He didn't take a blind bit of notice of me (= he ignored me).
It won't make the blindest bit of difference (= it will make no difference at all).

meanings.def: to pretend not to notice something bad that is happening, so you do not have to do anything about it
examples: The authorities were either unaware of the problem or they turned a blind eye to it.
She’s as blind as a bat without her glasses.

idioms.def: a situation in which people with almost no experience or knowledge give advice to others who also have no experience or knowledge
when you love somebody, you cannot see their faults

idioms.idiom: not a blind bit/the blindest bit of…
examples: He didn't take a blind bit of notice of me (= he ignored me).
It won't make the blindest bit of difference (= it will make no difference at all).

idioms.def: to pretend not to notice something bad that is happening, so you do not have to do anything about it
examples: The authorities were either unaware of the problem or they turned a blind eye to it.

meanings.def: to permanently destroy somebody’s ability to see
examples: She was blinded in the explosion.
The attackers blinded him with acid.
The strong light almost blinded him.

meanings.def: to make it difficult for somebody to see for a short time
examples: When she went outside she was temporarily blinded by the sun.
His eyes were blinded by tears.

meanings.def: to make somebody no longer able to think clearly or behave in a sensible way
examples: His sense of loyalty blinded him to the truth.

meanings.def: to confuse somebody by using technical or complicated language that they do not understand
to use swear words
examples: There was a lot of effing and blinding going on.

idioms.def: to confuse somebody by using technical or complicated language that they do not understand

examples: There was a lot of effing and blinding going on.

meanings.def: material that covers a window, often consisting of a roll of cloth that is fixed at the top of the window and can be pulled up and down
examples: She saw a figure through the blinds.
Pull up the blinds and let some light in.

meanings.def: something people say or do to hide the truth about something in order to trick other people
without being able to see; using instruments only
extremely drunk
examples: He came home blind drunk, as usual.

meanings.def: to cheat or trick somebody so that they lose a lot of money
examples: You can’t trust them. They’ll rob you blind as soon as your back is turned.

meanings.def: to say that something is definitely true
examples: He swore blind that he’d already paid back the money he owed me.
He swore blind that you knew all about it.
He came home blind drunk, as usual.

idioms.def: to cheat or trick somebody so that they lose a lot of money
examples: You can’t trust them. They’ll rob you blind as soon as your back is turned.

idioms.def: to say that something is definitely true
examples: He swore blind that he’d already paid back the money he owed me.
He swore blind that you knew all about it.
